text: I want to register VCF.jl that obviously does not meet the auto-merge guidelines. If you have comments on the package name, I'd like your input here or at <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/30036>

text: I would favor VariantCallFormat.jl, just because VCF is too short, and could easily clash with others. Also, I would guess most people using VCF files would know what it stood for.

elements.text: I would favor VariantCallFormat.jl, just because VCF is too short, and could easily clash with others. Also, I would guess most people using VCF files would know what it stood for.

text:
My arguments for `VCF.jl` over `VariantCallFormat.jl` are:
* Slighly easier to find the package. People in bioinformatics tend to talk about VCF files more than Variant Call Format. It's likely you get a VCF file from some tool that  you need to analyze. So the starting point is always "VCF".
* It's common for other file format packages use this convention, e.g. `CSV.jl` and `XLSX.jl`.
* The package `VCFTools.jl` also choose `VCF` over `VariantCallFormat`.

The main argument for `VariantCallFormat.jl` is that it is more descriptive. And that's a good argument. :slightly_smiling_face: I would be happy to switch. Let's see if someone else wants to weigh in.

text: As a note, the pure file format packages in BioJulia all(?) have names related to the file endings. E.g. `FASTX`, `XAM`, `GFF3`.
